metadata.case_name: Appellants (Collector of Bombay etc.) v. First Respondent (Owner of Irani Manzil)

facts.text: The first respondent was the owner of three shops situated on the ground floor of the premises known as Irani Manzil.
The property was requisitioned on 15th April 1943 by the Collector of Bombay under rule 75-A of the Defence of India Rules read with Notification dated 15th April 1942.

Requisition order (No. M.S.C. 467/H): Necessary for public safety and efficient prosecution of war; possession delivered to Food Controller, Bombay; continued during present war and six months thereafter or shorter period specified by Food Controller.
Premises used for housing Government Grain Shop No. 176.
Letter dated 30th July 1946/17th August 1946 from Controller of Government Grain Shops to first respondent: Requisition validity expires 30th September 1946; allow Department to remain as tenants.
First respondent's advocates replied 27th August 1946 offering tenancy on certain terms, which were not accepted.
Occupation continued after 30th September 1946; first respondent complained about continued occupation and contemplated transfer to private party.
Notice dated 29th August 1947 from first respondent's advocates to Collector: Vacate shops giving two clear calendar months; deliver peaceful vacant possession.
Letter 1st October 1947 from Controller: Second respondent handed over Government Grain Shop No. 176; first respondent to consent to electric connection.
First respondent refused consent and protested.
Letter 15th January 1948 from Collector to first respondent: Requisition continued after 30th September 1946 by Act XVII of 1947; possession handed to second respondent; no vacant possession.
Correspondence: Collector admitted subletting to second respondent but contended maintenance of essential supplies justified continued requisition.

Suit No. 235 of 1949 filed by first respondent in Bombay High Court original side against appellants (defendants 1 and 2) and second respondent (defendant 3) for vacant peaceful possession and compensation for wrongful use and occupation.
Appellants contested suit; second respondent filed no written statement and did not contest.

Trial Judge Mr. Justice Coyajee decreed suit upholding plaintiff's contentions: requisition expired; no longer under requisition; purpose-specific and purpose ceased; post-Aug 1947 user by State not Dominion; ceased by Act IX 1951.
Appeal No. 117 of 1952 to Bombay High Court: Confirmed decree on short point re clause 3 Ordinance No. XIX 1946; no further extension; declined other points.
High Court rejected leave to appeal to Supreme Court; special leave granted under Article 136.
Defence of India Act 1939 and rules expire 30th September 1946; various properties requisitioned would end.
Ordinance No. XIX 1946 promulgated 26th September 1946 by Governor-General under s.72 Government of India Act.

legal_issues.text: Construction of clause 3 of the Requisitioned Land Continuance of Powers Ordinance, 1946 (No. XIX of 1946): Whether it continued the requisitioning order beyond its specified duration (war + 6 months, expiring 30th September 1946).
Other points raised by first respondent: requisition purpose-specific and ceased; post-Aug 1947 user by State Government not Dominion; ceased by Act IX 1951.

petitioner_arguments.text: Clause 3 continues all requisitioned lands (immovable properties subject to requisition under Defence of India Act/rules on 30th Sep 1946) until expiry of Ordinance, regardless of limited or indefinite duration in order; plain grammatical construction; non-obstante clause clarifies by abundant caution, does not cut down clear terms.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ordinance No. XIX of 1946, cl.2 (definition), cl.3; Defence of India Act 1939

respondent_arguments.text: Requisition order expired by its terms on 30th Sep 1946 (war+6m); clause 3 only continues orders that would cease solely due to Act expiry, not those with inherent limited duration; non-obstante supports this; purpose (war) ceased; post-1947 user by wrong government; Act IX 1951 ended.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ordinance No. XIX 1946 cl.3; Defence of India Act 1939; Act IX 1951

court_reasoning.text: Preamble and cl.3 address emergency from Act expiry; definition of requisitioned land covers properties subject to requisition on expiry date; cl.3 continues all such until Ordinance expiry; non-obstante does not cut down plain meaning; strict construction but clear terms cover limited duration orders too.
court_reasoning.key_observation: All immovable properties subject to requisition on 30 Sep 1946 continued, whether limited or indefinite duration.

court_reasoning.text: Courts cannot speculate on legislative intent against clear words; equities not for court; remand necessary as High Court decided only short point, not others.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court erred on cl.3; other points undecided.

holdings.text: Clause 3 of Ordinance XIX 1946 continued the requisition order as property was subject to requisition on 30 Sep 1946.
Remand appeal to High Court to decide all points raised before trial court.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Act, 1939 (XXXV of 1939)
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers for requisition exercised thereunder; expired 30 Sep 1946

statutes_cited.name: Requisitioned Land (Continuance of Powers) Ordinance, 1946 (No. XIX of 1946)
statutes_cited.relevance: Continued requisitions post Defence Act expiry; central issue of construction

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Power for Governor-General to promulgate Ordinance XIX 1946

statutes_cited.name: Requisitioned Land (Continuance of Powers) Act, 1947 (Act XVII of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Mentioned by Collector as continuing requisition

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed appeal in part by holding that clause 3 of Ordinance XIX 1946 continued the requisition; reversed High Court on that point; remanded Appeal No. 117/1952 to Bombay High Court to decide all other points raised before trial court; no order for costs.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand to High Court for full adjudication

key_quotes.text: "all requisitioned lands shall continue to be subject to requisition until the expiry of this Ordinance"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core text of cl.3 Ordinance XIX 1946 interpreted broadly

key_quotes.text: "If the words of the enactment are clear and are capable of only one interpretation on a plain and grammatical construction of the words thereof, a non obstante clause cannot cut down that construction"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key principle rejecting respondent's non-obstante argument

key_quotes.text: "We cannot help remanding the matter to the Court of appeal with a direction that the appeal be disposed of on all the points which were dealt with by the trial Court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
